newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian official criticises Kulikov over Chechnya.
newsitem.headline: Russian official criticises Kulikov over Chechnya.

text.p: A senior Russian official on Saturday accused Interior Minister Anatoly Kulikov of hampering progress towards lasting peace in breakaway Chechnya by blocking a prisoner exchange.

Boris Berezovsky, deputy secretary of Russia's policy-making Security Council, told a news conference that he was perplexed by Kulikov's behaviour over the exchange, which involved 11 special policemen who fall within his ministry's remit.

"I am at a loss to understand the interior minister's position on this issue," Berezovsky said. "Kulikov, who should be concerned above all about helping to free people, especially because they are his people who are being held."

Kulikov, who was not immediately available for comment on the charge, has been accused before of taking a hawkish line over Chechnya, torn by 21 months of fighting between local separatists and Russian troops.

He commanded Moscow's military campaign in Chechnya before being appointed minister in July 1995 and is the only senior official involved in the conflict to have survived a subsequent sweep-out of hardliners by President Boris Yeltsin.
The biggest clash came when former Security Council Secretary Alexander Lebed, who organised a truce in Chechnya in August, asked Yeltsin to choose between himself and Kulikov.
Yeltsin told Kulikov to stay on and later sacked Lebed, accusing him of overstepping his position and having overt presidential ambitions.

Berezovsky, a business magnate whose appointment to the Security Council last year sparked a row over his suitability for the job, played a key role in securing last month's peace deal which built on the August ceasefire.
He said that Kulikov's move was particularly unhelpful now that Moscow had decided to tell the truth and keep its promises to the Chechens.

"What happened before was that the federal centre played a cheating game with the Chechen side. I don't want to say whether the Chechen side cheated the federal centre or not. What's very important is that we have fundamentally changed our position."

Berezovsky said that, as agreed, the Chechens had handed over a list of three Chechen prisoners they wanted released in return for freeing the 11 policemen, along with the places they were being held.
"Kulikov said they weren't in the places mentioned, but a bit later, about a month, I found out they were there," he said. "Here we suddenly come across an obstacle. I think it's completely wrong."

Berezovsky, who took part in the latest round of talks with the separatists, which brought a memorandum on transporting oil across Chechnya, declined to give details of the deal, saying only that Russia had to pay for peace in Chechnya.

The security of the pipeline, which runs from Azerbaijan to the Russian Black Sea port of Novorossiisk, is important for an international consortium involved in an $8 billion deal to extract oil from the Caspian Sea.
The consortium plans to send the first oil through the pipeline by October.

Berezovsky said he could not rule out a return to the conflict if hawks came to the helm in Russia, but that Yeltsin had done much "to correct the situation at the end of 1994", when he launched his military campaign.
Hundreds of prisoners, both Chechens and Russian soldiers remain in capitivity and a recent spate of kidnappings of journalists in Chechnya have complicated the peace process.
But Berezovsky said that both he and Chechen President Aslan Maskhadov were determined to make sure that everyone was freed.
